text: I have a real treat for you today it's a
lemon pound cake and it's not just one
lemon pound cake it's two lemon pound
cake so you can make two you could
freeze one or you can take it to your
friends at work or you can hoard it in
your closet hide it from your children
whatever you want to do you might want
to do the last option because it's so
delicious
in this measuring cup I have 3/4 of a
cup of buttermilk to that I'm adding the
zest of two whole lemons so it's a very
lemony pound cake there will also be
lemon juice to add it after a third of a
cup depends on how juicy your lemons are
as how many that will be at least one
probably like one and a half you can add
your lemon juice straight to your
buttermilk mixture and then just set it
aside while you whisk your dry
ingredients in this bowl I have three
cups of all-purpose flour give it a
little whisk add a teaspoon and a half
of coarse salt if you're using fine salt
use 3/4 of a teaspoon otherwise your
cakes will be really salty half a
teaspoon of baking powder also a half a
teaspoon of baking soda whisk whisk
whisk be sure to whisk everything evenly
set that aside then get your pans ready
I have 2 4 and 1/2 by 8 and 1/2 inch
pans they need to be buttered and
floured so have some room temperature
butter and a pastry brush I find this is
the best way to butter when I was
growing up we used to just take the
piece of butter in the little wrapper
and rub it inside but it's not as you
don't get into the corners as well and
you don't get the coverage that you get
if you use a pastry brush flour your
pans as well so just dust with a little
bit of flour making sure that gets all
over anywhere there's butter the flour
will stick this helps removing your
cakes when they're done what you end up
with is a very fine coating of flour and
like I said that helps ensure that your
cakes remove very easily when they're
done in my mixer I have two cups of
sugar and two sticks of butter the
butter is also room temperature just
like the butter I used for buttering my
pans
Queen it until it's light and fluffy
it's particularly important with pound
cakes because this is what helps them
rise in addition to those leaveners it's
the creaming process that really keeps
them nice and light and tender
same thing goes for the eggs in a
classic pound cake the only leavener
that's in there are the eggs so make
sure that you beat them really well and
get them nice and fluffy before you add
another egg
five large eggs once one egg is fully
combined add another one
start with your dry ingredients
you can add your dry mixture as the
machine is going if you dare not a lot
of room the remaining liquid and then
the remaining dry ingredients and that's
your batter make sure your oven is
preheating to 350 degrees at this point
divide the batter evenly between your
prepared pans
these need to bake for 50 to 60 minutes
or until a toothpick inserted in the
center comes out clean after the cakes
come out of the oven cooled them in the
pans for 15 minutes and then turn them
out onto a wire rack to cool completely
you want them on the wire rack to help
with cooling but also because tada
you're going to glaze them and you want
the glaze to drip down into the pan
below so make your glaze this is 2 cups
of confectioner's sugar and you'll add 3
maybe 4 tablespoons of fresh lemon juice
start with like 2 and then whisk in and
you want to be careful sometimes this
turns into like a syrupy glaze it won't
coat anything in like a matter of second
so add your lemon juice slowly what
you're looking for is a sort of smooth
pourable glaze that coats your cakes now
I'm going to glaze theoretically you're
supposed to wait until the glaze sets
before you eat this so I don't know make
some plans that make it so you have to
go out for about 30 minutes otherwise
you're probably going to eat it right
away you can skip the glaze but why
would you want to all the excess will
drip down onto the pan that's easy to
clean up
now all you have to do is wait this is
one amazing over-the-top lemon pound
cake one for now one for later
hi guys thanks for watching this video
